div.p: Looke about You: OR, A word in Season to a Divided Nation.

q.l: Never was yet a Nation
Vndone by too much caution.

div.p: LONDON: Printed for Robert Bostock, & are to be sold at his shop at the sign of the Kings head in Pauls Church yard. 1647.

div.head: Looke about you: OR A word in season to a divided NATION, &c.
div.p:
FEw or none but agree joyntly in the chief working and procuring cause of all our Calamity wch hath deformed and dis-figured three so famous Realms and Dominions; all Professors Protestant acknowledging it sent by God, 3 Amos 6. as deserved and procured by sinne, 2 ler. 17-4.18. All the question is of the principall instruments among men, who have the chiefe hand in acting and fomenting of such an universall and cruell designe against Liberty, and (which is the life of soules, and soule of life) Religion, Quaritur, whose Agents are these unhappy (however successefull) instruments? who sets them on worke? Grant,59 Esa. 2. our sinnes have separated our Kingdome from God; but who hath so farr engaged and embroiled the miserably-divided Inhabitants one against another? Is not the hand of Ioah in all this? Is it not a party (and a great one too, however too securely and presumptuously slighted of such as are ignorant of, or not well read in their principles and practises) whose Religion and Resolution is to Divide and destroy Kings and Princes, People and Nations not a few? who Preach and Print, Divide & Impera for a fundamentall Doctrine, which in plaine English explains
their mystery of iniquity, and gives light enough to guesse at, if not openly discover, their blacke Art of building upon others ruine: knowing the Ark will not let Dagon stand, and Bethel will not give Babel a Toleration, for God is not the author of Confusion. 1 Cor. 14.33.

I remember your Proverbe, if milke burne too, The Bishop's foot is in it. Hath not the Jesuite a chief hand in making our seething Nation burne too, and boile over into the fire of his owne kindling; Vid. Mr. Pe

‚Ä¢ pistle to his ‚Ä¢ reatise of the ‚Ä¢ ate myste
‚Ä¢ es of the Je
‚Ä¢ uites, Tran
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ated out of ‚Ä¢ rench, and ‚Ä¢ rinted at
‚Ä¢ ondon for N. ‚Ä¢ utter. A. D. ‚Ä¢ 523. who (under the sweet name of Jesus) preacheth and publisheth little * else then Fire, Marder, & Sedition? But he is so cunning a Sophister as to play least in sight when he is most in action; and to promote the publike ruine, whilst he sits, and plots, and acts in private, (as becomes the Younger brother of Perdition) ad ruinam Natus, borne to undoe a Nation. This is Ioannes de Altrado, that will personate any man or calling, if so be he may compleate all he hath been plotting: The Iack behinde the hedge (I knew not the meaning or use of the old Fable till of late) (who sets the Gyants together by the eares.
‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ pus in Fa
‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ . In a word, the crafty Knave at shore, that stands laughing in his sleeve, and clapping his hands for joy to see the hot skirmish at Sea of his owne making.

Seduced Countrey-men, who hath bewitched you with a sottish ignorance of the course which three Kingdoms are now running in full careere to their owne undoing? If yee bee not blinde on both eyes, you can hardly avoid the sight of one behind the Curtaine in the retiring room, who dresseth all or most Actors of this Bloudy, Popish, Hellish, Jesuiticall Tragedy, which have so happily (to the rejoycing of their once-within-this-six-years-drooping spirits, & answer of their earnest desires and longing expectation; as they are not ashamed to make their brags) gone through and acted over most of the Scenes in Ireland (almost undone by their meanes, and now in all probability, (without an intervening
miracle of Divine mercy) neare a compleate ruine by their present Designe, the Master-piece of their chief Head piece Satan and his Vicar Antichrist) that he is esteemed more then halse an Infidell among those Brethren in Catholick Conspiracy, and Universall Iniquity, who seems to have the least shadow of scruple or doube of finishing the last Scene and Act, and concluding with the ten-Thousand times more unmercifull and altogether Diabolicopapa-Jesuiticall Epilogue in Englands finall overthrow and desolation. Quod avertat Dew! is my frequent and fervent Prayer; and I know herein I doe not pray alone, having all well-wishers to Gods Truth and England's Peace, daily instant Orators at the Throne of Grace to beare me company. Exaudinos Domine.
Fellow-Citizens, and fellow-souldiers,

Will you have a taste of these seeming holy Fathers unholy Principles, shall I give you some hint of their bloudy practices? I hope a word of instruction will not be out of season to pave the way to caution and admonition; having in brief acquainted you with some of their inaccessible mysteries.
These and such like are the Articles of their Creed, whose faith is faction.

1. The Pope of Rome hath all power in his hand,Ludov. Luci ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ Hist, Iesuit. „Äà‚óä„Äâ
2. p. 177, 179, &c. both Spirituall and Temporall; to command and forbid, to excommunicate and punish, to make and unmake Emperors, Kings, Princes and Magistrates of all sorts, to grvernetheir Realmes and Subjects at his pleasure. Hee that doth not give credit to this as an article of Faith, approve and obey it is accounted and abhorred as an Heretick.‚ÄîThis is held and maintained in the writings of Platina, Sylvester Prierias, Bellarmine, Bezius, Pezantius, Suavez & others of Satan's Chaplains in ordinary, but the Holy Ghost in Scripture speaks clean contrary. 62 Psa. 11. Mat 9.6.-18.18-6.13-1 Cor. 15.24. 4 Rev. 11.-5.12, 13-19 1, &c.
Mark I beseech you how contrary to Scripture, yea nature, and publique welfare, the principles of Jesuits are. Need I bid you abhorre the Treason?

2. All the Constitutions, Covenants, Agreements, Capitulations, Grants, that any Emperour, King, Prince, or any other (who is not of the present Roman-Catholique Religion, or professeth any other) due make, are void and null, though ratified and confirmed by an oath since the Pope approves them not. Jacob. Simancha. One of their famous Scribes maintaines, There ought be no commerce or peace with Heretiques, &c. If any promise or oath have beene made and given, it ought in no wise to be kept. Conradus Brunus writes, There can be no peace betweene a Catholique and Heretique; it is an unjust and blasphemous condition, Qu√¢ Haretisis permittitur ut dogmata sua doceant, Togive any leave to vent any other then Cathalique doctrine‚ÄîPetrus Ribadeneira, Martinus Becanus, Antonius Possevinus, sing to the same tune‚ÄîA man shall as soon find Peace as Truth, and Truth as Peace among these Catholique Impostors, Soule-cheaters, and both ad Gracas Kalendas, are like to kisse in the Romish Sea where Apollyon domineers. Who would serve under such Enemies of Peace and Truth? Looke about you (fellow-souldiers) give no tolleration for such to lurke among you, and put their bloody designes in execution by you. This is their Principle, you may read out their horrid practice, as full of blood and neer to ruine, as they are far from Peace.
When they pretend to exhort to, and plead for Peace, beleeve them not;5 Psal, 20. for (as David said) They speak not Peace, but they devise deceitfull matters against them that are quiet in the Land.
Lord how long wilt thou look on? Rescue my soule from their destructions-35. Psal. 17.

Take the Jesuit's character, see him drawne to the life by the pensill of the holy Ghost in holy Scripture;5 Psal. 20. He hath put forth his hands against such as be at Peace with him; he hath
broken [or prophaned] his Covenant.5 Psal. 21. The words of his mauth were smoother then butter, but Warre was in his heart: his words were softer then oyle, yet were they drawne Swords.

O that God would open the eyes of such as live neare or dwell among these men of blood, these sonnes of Belial, that at last, espying how they have beene deluded, they may every one, open his mouth in such words as he uttered upon the discovery of such a crastie Generation.120 Psal. 6, 7. My soule hath long dwelt with him that hateth Peace. I am for Peace (or a man of Peace) but when I speake, they are for Warr: Whom I may describe by this Motto, Mel in orefel in corde; A pot of Gall cover'd over with Hony. So I leave their second Principle, as another Article of their Creed, and come to a third.

3. It is the Dutie of all Catholiques every where, to doe what in them lyeth, by Fire, Sword, Poyson, Gunpowder, War, and other such like Plots and Stratagems, to oppresse and take out of the way all Heretiques with their abettors, as also all Politique Catholiques,Sio Jesuitae consiliarios Principum Pontificiorum, pacis studiosos, cognominant. who study and endeavour to keep Peace & live at quiet, rather then assist and put to their helping hand for the suppression and extirpation of Heretiques.

Ribadeneira, P. Chirlandus, Simancha, and others of those disloyall Loyallists,Orat. ad Car. 5. Imper. write at large of this point‚ÄîCardinall Poole perswaded Charles the fifth, to leave the Turkes and goe against the Heretiques; His n. compositis, mineri negotie reliqua aggredi ac perficere poteris. A Turc√¢ minus periculi imminst. i.e. When you have quieted them, you may goe on with mere ease against the Turke. So another of these Gowned Assassines, in his Oration to the Emperour Maximilian the second, saith‚ÄîQuamdiu non equum tuum in Lather anorum sanguine ventre-tenus natare feceris; cogitare minim√® debes, te fortun√¢bon√¢ aut victori√¢ contra Turcam. potiturum esse. It's in vaine to imagine or dreame of any good successe,
much lesse of a victory against the Grand Seignear, untill your horse can swim up to the belly in Lutheran gore. Conradus Brunus, Windeck, Petrus Stewartus, Muthias Meyerhofer, Stapleton, Baronius, Ribadencira, Becanus, father Garnet, Hill, and Creswell, (all true Jesuits, though never a True manamong them) with one heart and subscribe to this Article, and conspire in this bloody Religion, which is built on the foundation of lying and destroying, as it is written and copied out in blood and gall: the professors and practisers of which,8 Rev. 11. are such blazing Comets and falling Starres, as embitter all the waters they light upon.

q.l: Be wise at last ye Popish Kings,
These Iesuits are divilish things.
If peaceable and moderate,
Your life, they teach, is out of date.
They call you Politique, make it good,
For these vow they will have your blood.
If this be their Religion,
What's Murder and Rebellion?

div.p: 4. Take one more in the last place to make up the quaternio and squadron-. Whensoever Roman-Catholique Subjects doe judge, and in their councells or meetings conclude, that the Emperour, King, or Prince, under whom they live, is a Tyrant, they may depose him, and are dis-engaged from all homage and obedience to him: If the Emperour, or King, or Prince, doe forbid their meetings together, then may any Subject, having advised with the Jesuits, kill the King, and therein is accounted by them to doe a praise-worthy and meritorious act. Hit erro adde, that if they have a Lutheran, or any other Heretique for their King, who labours to make the Subjects all of his Religion, then they hold all the Subjects free from engagement and subjection to him, and it's free for them to depose, root out, or suppresse him, to kill, or poyson him‚Äî
So doe they write of this, as if such onely deserved the Bayes and Crowne who had done some such like Act.
See Ioh. Mariana de rege, lib. 1. cap. 6. who tells us, that in all ages, in magn√¢ laude fu√™re, quicun{que} Tyrannos opprimere aggressi sunt.

So doe they tye Kings at their girdle, that if any Prince refuse to give eare to their counsells (which cannot be good, comming from men of such corrupt and bloody principles) presently they give an allarme to the Subjects, whose licence to Rebell and Kill is subscribed with their Imprimatur‚Äî

With him walkes Creswell, ali√¢s Philopater, hand-in-hand together‚ÄîWith these joyne Guignard, Reinald, Veronaus, Ioh. Gueret Castellius, (Sainted or Chronicled for a Martyr in remembrance of his killing one of the Henry's of France) who have the approbation and good-liking of their whole Colleges‚Äî

For what came Parry over to England in the 26 of Queen Eliz. (of famous and pious memory, for Valour,v. Acta Henrici Garneti. Wisedome, and Vertue) but to make away with the Queene, as one whom the Pope had excommunicated‚Äî

To what other end came Garnet Tesmond, and Gerrard, (prime Jesuits) with their accomplices into this Nation,1605. but to undermine and blow up King, and Nobles, & Commons, both Houses of Parliament, Governours and Government at once.‚Äî

They pretend a reason, as Suarez writes, Rex hareticus, Suar. Defens. fdeiCatho. contra Anel. Sect. Error. l. 6. c. 4.
statim per heresim ipso facto privatur alique modo dominie & proprietate sui regni: quiavel confiscatum manct, vel ad legitimum successorem Catholicum ipse jure transit. As if a King could no sooner leave or oppose the Catholike Religion, but he makes an absolute forfeiture of, and loseth all right to his Kingdome and Dominion: As if it were to be a Rule,
No Catholike, No King; which they can never make good by all their Sophistry, although it should be supposed that we give them leave to screw up their witty equivocation to the highest pegge. Let them have Simancha, Tresham, Creswell, Mariana, which last Scribe wrote a book of Regicide or King-slaying, (which he approves and maintains tooth and naile, as if he intended the next step and remove into the Papall throne.) Which fiery Treatise was commanded to the fire at Paris, after publique censure by a Parliamentary Edict. Whereupon one admonished the French in such a manner:

q.l: Galli, si sapitis, quid librum traditis igni?
Authores vestris pellite limitibus.
In cineres abiit liber unus; mille relicti.
Horumturbaloquax; mutus at ille fuit.
Hortos qui capiunt penit√πs purg are veneno
Radices properant vellere; non folia.

div.p: Which may be Englished plainly thus, in our plaine habit.

q.l: Ye French, if wise, the book why doe yee burne?
Out of your Coasts the Authors rather turne.
One Book's to ashes gone; a thousand stay.
These are more talkative, but that was dumbe.
They that would Orchards quite of poisen rid,
Pluck up the root, not leaves; or wish they did.

div.p: To pull the fruit of this bitter Tree that growes on such a root of killing and poisonous principles, in France or our own Kingdoms, would aske more time then I have to write, and as much patience more as you have to read.

I am already tyr'dout with leaking in this kennel of bloudhounds, and raking in this bloudy channell of their irreligious religion, and pretended faith so much worse then professed Insidelity, that I cannot measure in my apprehension, much lesse parallell in my expression, I should think I said enough, having sent you back to three dying Realmes, experience
of Jesuiticall treachery and cruelty, which rigged the Spanish Navy in 88, and another Armado within this 8 or 9 yeares, in their conceit as likely to prove invincible as the former. But I shal not adventure beyond my time or leisure. All I have to say, is to relate one or two late stories, which I conceive to be of some observation not altogether unworthy.

When I was lately in London, About May, 1647. M. Bodin Mini ster of the Bath. as I passed by Pauls Churchyard, I spyed a friend in a Stationer's Shop, who, after salutes passed, with some briefe discourse of the times, informed mee of some late newes out of Italy arrived at his hands in a Letter from a friend, concerning a meeting not very long since among the Popish Priests, and others; whereat, a question being put, (How to reduce England to Rome?) after many had risen up & given in their best advice, An antient Fryar begins to speak in such a manner; It is not Fire and Faggot, not the Sword, not Powder-plots, that can effect it; you thought well on another meanes, viz. to worke upon, and gaine in the King and Nobles; but no way, in my judgement like this, viz. Set the Puritan against the Preacher and the worke is done.

I then thought, and (as I remember) said, They have now their work done to their hands; which is their master-plot and grand engine, to pull down more by their policy then ever they could throw down with their pieces of battery. You see the Popish eggs are not all addle, if one device doth not, another may, and will take, and reach as far as God will permit, but further it cannot. This is one, the other followes.

Calling to see a friend at Putny, The Minister of Barns. he told me of a Merchat in the same house then present, who related unto him an History, or rather some late experience then Intelligence, then (as he said) not a week old.

Few dayes before he was walking in London, About some part of May. and seeing a multitude at a doore, he asked who preached there? A woman answered, One whom they count an Anabaptist, but he is a very Good Able Man. He resolv'd to stay and heare, and upon hearing of the Sermon, he was much taken with the mans parts and abilities: all
done, he tooke more notice of the man, thinking he had seene him of late beyond the Seas, and, taking him by the hand, salutes him, Sir, doe you not remember me? The Preacher denyes that ever he saw him. At length, he so describes himselfe, and writes him as it were a Copy of the place, time, company, in such Characters as he admired, and hereupon said, Sir, If you betray me, &c.‚Äîputting his hand to his neck. But, I wonder, said the Merchant, how you came to pray and preach so vehemently for puritie of Ordinances, &c. just as some among us.‚ÄîHe answered, Our College can reach any of parts, that in a fortnight. The Merchant againe, Sir, but you are not of this judgement and way, as you pretend here, are you? No, saith he, but you know Divide & Impera. This Merchant, as the Minister informed me, said, This was a Jesuit whom he saw in Rome sew moneths agoe.

By what I have read concerning the Principles and practices of these men, I have ground to imagine. There is not one Sect or opinion in this or any other Realme, which some or other of them doe not pretend to be of and joyne with, if so be they may hereby play their owne game, and make others drive all day long in their mill blindfold, to advance the Catholike Cause here and elsewhere. They cannot fish but in troubled waters, every one can tell how good fishing they must needs find here, if they had none elsewhere.

I am sorry I took no more punctuall notice of them, who informed me concerning a Jesuit, who playd his game so well, that he got into a Living of late yeares, and kept undiscovered, untill one travelling on the way, being forced to lye in that Town, and resolving to hear one on the Lords day in that place, heard him, and (thinking he knew him) would have had him come to his Inne, but the noise of this invitation deprived them of an afternoon Sermon, the Preacher being fled. It's not unknown to him that knows any thing of the Jesuits doctrines, that they use to train up many to seduce and deceive as well as to kill and destroy.

Having bin excited, partly by a friend who is a wel-wisher, but more by my hearty wel-wishes to, and desires of the glory of God and the publique good, I could not but hold forth an Item for my Country-mens admonition, and (If I live doe no more for them, which is knowne best unto God, and him onely) intreat them to beware of the Jesuits within (lust, & a deceitfull heart) and without, viz. those brats of Ignatius, or rather fire-brands, that kindle distractions in Church and State all the world over;8 Joh. who descend more remotely from their father the Devill, who is the father of a lye, and a murderer ab initio, abominable for antiquitie; but more immediately derive their pedigree from Ignatius Loiola that carried fire in his name, whom some of the JesuitsSalmanassar. doe acknowledge to have bin by nature fierce, hard, and cruel. This cruel and butcherly nature and bloody disposition he derived unto his followers, who may well be named the Bloody disciples, the fi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ry Sect. Farewell Reader, Take heed, and say, Ye bad morning.
